div.p:
This implementation guide provides a framework which can be adopted to ensure messaging standards and compliance among implementers. In other words, this is a governing framework that issues messaging requirements (allowed codes and code systems), specifies the minimum required data elements per FHIR resource and also has control over which data elements are mandatory.
Systems must be able to talk the same lanuguage otherwise important information will be lost...
When preparing for the development of an implementation guide, the following key tasks will be essential.

ol.li: Define a minimum dataset (MDS): Identifify the informational requirements for specific use cases. I.e., what data elements are needed by the EMR and lab systems to be interoperable with regards to data availability?
Map the MDS fields to FHIR elements: Identify the appropriate FHIR resources and their data elements and establish a mapping with the MDS data elements.

div.p: The following will need to be installed on your machine to support the development and testing of an implementation guide.

ol.li: Visual Studio Code: A code editor.

Sushi: Enables FHIR shorthand which greatly reduces the complexities associated with implementation guide development.
Mitre has created an excellent reference article for the purpose of exploring and understanding Sushi. It is highly recommended that beginners carefully consult this great resource to assist with the development of an implementation guide.
Java: A platform used for the development and running of Java applications.
Jekyll: A static-site generator that allows for quick command line control over setup, deployment, and content management.
